Thats where you're wrong my friend. There are many different kinds of infinities and some are much larger than others eh heh
However, 2*infinity is the same cardinality as just plain old infinity, so while what you are saying is true, it is not applicable.

> 2*infinity is the same cardinality as just plain old infinity

I mean if we're talking technically you can't multiple infinity by anything because infinity is a concept, not a number or value at all.
But if we're applying that rule to Concepts, then numbers can't be multiplied either. Numbers are just symbolically representative concepts. ;p

No they arent :p. For example, I can actually prove that 2 times infinity does not equal infinity.

Saying 2 times infinity equals infinity is the same thing as saying 2X = X.The only time that 2X = X is when X = 0. Therefore by transitive relation infinity must equal 0, which it doesnt. Thus proving that 2 times infinity does not equal infinity

The problem here is the use of circular logic.
"Numbers" are a representative concept. Math is likewise a system of manipulating that concept within the scope of what it represents.

You claim that numbers exist, because they can or can't equal other numbers. But neither numbers nor math actually exist. Letters don't either, by this logic. They're all "concepts." ;p

infinity is a set of all numbers within certain boundaries. for instance, there are an infinite number of numbers between 1 and 2.  there is also an infinite amount of numbers between 1 and 100. 

The key difference is that the infinity encompassing 1 and 100 is much much larger than the infinity between 1 and 2. 

both numbers and infinity exist, its just that multiplying infinity by a number makes as much sense as dividing my zero :p. if that morg q hits ur gonna die regardless.

>both numbers and infinity exist 

Then show me a "1." *Not* the symbolic representation of a 1, but an actual 1.

Then you can prove mathematics, by explaining how real results can be achieved by *changing the rules*.
http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/great-debate-over-whether-1234-112-180949559/ 
(This is a real thing.)


Then you can finish by explaining how something that represents an absence of something is it's self something. Specifically, "0." 
(0 is a real thing in mathematics.)

--------------------------

Numbers are *concepts.* They don't exist in our physical reality. Likewise, the concepts we use to manipulate their representations, can also be changed. In that way, we can mathematically calculate infinities. Or we can use our concepts as proof that nothing = something within that conceptual field. 

------------------------

But yes. Morg Q's are scary.

30% increase. 

Brittle is however consumed when an immobilizing CC is applied, so it's not going to result in massively amped CC chains and can be partially wasted if consumed by a low duration immobilizing effect.
Does it work with suppression?
Ya, does it cause the effect to continue past the channel time, or does it cause the channel time to be longer?

>30% increase. 

Woo, [hole on one](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/yyMqPKxi-oh-look-another-champion-is-released-with-a-fuck-ton-of-knockups-tenacity-is-pretty-much-useless?comment=000400000000)!

So now for the important question: How does the 30% increase affect displacements? Will it only extend the stun duration, will victims travel further, will they just eat it with no effect?

***EDIT:***
Others are mentioning Suppression. Which is also a valid point for clarification.

Getting "Poppy'd" 30% farther would be fun to see.

Getting Morgana Q'd 30% longer would not.

We don't know how Poppy will react yet.

Morgana Q *will* be a thing though.

Meddler specifically mentioned immobilising CC, so I imagine it'd either consume it for no effect, or just work as usual.

How this works with things like Pulverise will be interesting though..

Displacements are considered immobilization though. That's why I ask.

Ignoring the brittle bonus seems the most consistent [with tenacity] and least likely to break something. But that would mean he's incapable of exploiting his own debuff. So it also seems the most illogical. 

Displacements could just ignore the extension and eat it for the bonus damage. But that creates dissonance in effect understanding and brings back the question, "why would *he* have it?"

If Displacement *is* extended by brittle, then there are a handful of different ways it could interact the relevant abilities. Never mind the shit-storm the forums will whip up over tenacity (which is already starting).

This would seem like an important point of clarification to me.
I think a flat increase would be more obnoxious than a %.
Imagine Trundle's Q slowing for 0.6 second instead of 0.1.
It's only immobilizing CC  (stuns, snares, roots), not _all_ CC like slows and silences.
